Anger as Theresa May locks reporters out of factory visit ahead of Devon trip By WMN_PGoodwin | Posted: May 02, 2017 9 COMMENTS SHARES Anger as Theresa May locks reporters out of factory visit ahead of Devon trip X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Comments (9) 
Prime Minister Theresa May's visit to Devon and Cornwall has sparked by media anger after she excluded some reporters from a factory visit. 
The PM – who visits Plymouth today – has been repeatedly been accused of keeping the public at bay during a stage managed campaign to secure an increased parliamentary majority. 
Mrs May, who last month announced a snap general election on June 8, toured AP Diving, a factory in Helston, Cornwall. 
Television crews were allowed inside to film the event but print and web journalists were locked in a room and banned from filming, Cornwall Live said. 
When given an audience with the PM, the reporters were allotted just three minutes and forbidden from asking questions about the the tight media controls. 
Lyn Barton, a reporter for Cornwall Live, said: "Having covered several high-profile politicians' and royal visits over the years, the level of media control here is far and above anything I've seen before. We're not even allowed to show you her visiting the building. Prime Minister Theresa May visits Helston - but we're not allowed to see what she does https://t.co/Wdad7j4Ew8 
— Emma Ferguson (@PacketEmma) May 2, 2017 Mrs May visited Cornwall briefly to support her fellow Conservative MPs, who hold all six seats west of the Tamar.
She visited along with Derek Thomas, the MP for St Ives and the Isles of Scilly constituency, after talking about the importance of local businesses in a rural economy in Parliament. 
Ahead of the visit, which ended with a trip to Devon, she released a statement setting out her campaign message. 
During a quick 'huddle' with reporters, Mrs May reiterated her themes of strong leadership in answers to the two questions alloted to Cornwall Live. 
In answer to questions about a funding crisis in Cornwall's health,social care and education sector, she said it was important to look at the broader picture. Local Cornish media getting a taste of Theresa May's approach to campaigning https://t.co/dpXUIwqxXC pic.twitter.com/eW0u2gWwOL — Ian Dunt (@IanDunt) May 2, 2017 
Referring to Brexit, she said "we stand at a crucuial moment" and that we must "get the right deal in Britain." 
Mrs May added: "That is about strong and stable leadership."
